stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: U.S. Government Agency Host Compromised by Sweet Orange Exploit Kit
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 13 September 2014, a U.S. Government Agency host was compromised by an unidentified actor after the host visited a tactical weapons web forum. The original source indicates that the exploit kit that was used was likely the Sweet Orange Exploit Kit.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
After visiting the tactical weapons web forum site, the U.S Government Agency host was redirected to a German-registered server with IP address 87.118.127.94. The server was found to be hosting the domains "palmsprings.pulaskiammo.com" and "pallet.penstorageboxes.com". When the host was redirected from the tactical weapons forum, an exploit kit closely resembling Sweet Orange was used to download an unidentified Flash exploit and compromise the U.S Government Agency host. The successful execution of the exploit code caused the victim to download binary malware installation code. The presence of executable malware installation code confirmed that the Flash exploit had successfully breached the security of the host and that the host had been compromised.
Analysis of the binary installation code revealed that the executable, when run, contacts the domain "openisp.su". This domain was registered on 8 September 2014 and was shared by at least twelve different IP addresses. They were as follows:
IP Address Country of Registration
74.12.221.165 Canada 78.62.94.153 Latvia 109.104.172.69 Ukraine 109.254.116.68 Ukraine 141.101.11.233 Ukraine 176.8.126.213 Ukraine 213.231.60.190 Ukraine 46.119.226.231 Ukraine 46.160.100.172 Ukraine 89.209.96.153 Ukraine 93.171.78.27 Ukraine 94.231.32.32 Ukraine
The use of multiple IPs for a single domain resolution suggests that the openisp.su domain may be part of a Fast-Flux forensic countermeasure involving multiple domains and IPs which change over time.
Additional research also found that approximately 200 domain names are are associated with the IP address 87.118.127.94.
Technical descriptions of the Sweet Orange Exploit Kit: http://malware-traffic-analysis.net/2014/08/20/index.html http://malware-traffic-analysis.net/2014/08/21/index2.html http://www.invincea.com/2013/03/k-i-a-defense-contractor-website-as-a-watering-hole-sweet-orange-ek-stopped-by-invincea/ http://threatpost.com/israeli-think-tank-site-serves-sweet-orange-exploit/108119
